column4: I know there are many text editors in linux, which one is worth getting used to ?
vi
it may not mean 'core' as in cpu cores
there is no way to tell and it's different for each mobo, it comes with a hardcoded list of possible sensor names for different chips
I dont understand how Hyperthreading makes me get 2 readings for core temperature. Does Hyperthreading involve setting a second diode in the chipset ?
the 'cores' that sensors talk about are probably not cpu cores
your cpu may have two temperature probes, or sensors may be giving the wrong names
I see, so most likely it is reffering to the MB and Core0 temperatures... at least by the numbers i get it makes sense
there is a file in /etc/ that you can modify so the sensors are correctly labelled
cool, assuming i know which is which :P
all it does is detect sensor chips, there is no trivial way to detect which sensors are for what
which /etc/ should i mess around with ?
/etc/sensors or similar iirc
/etc/sensors.conf ?
that's the one
so why do the sensor labels not match up?
I meant that someone has already come accross my problem and edited the sensors.conf file, so i dont have to break my head which sensors does what
so your sensors are labelled correctly?
i am trying to understand which lines i need to edit
apparently, the sensors.conf files does contain some of the correct labels, but they are commented out.
ah i see
the trick is figuring out what type of MB chipset you have, in my case, i believe it is "it8716-*" though the motherboard is ASUS M2NPV-VM
sensors will tell you the chip it is reading from
